bibl.title: The Scribe as Interpreter: A New Look at New Testament Textual Criticism According to Reader Reception Theory.
bibl.note: Diss. Univ. of South Africa. Summary in DA 59 (1998-1999) p. 110-A. - The first section deals with the literary theory of reader reception as it pertains to Christian Egyptian scribes living in the second and third centuries A.D.; the second section provides a detailed analysis of the actual receptions and textual variants produced by three Christian Egyptian scribes - i.e., those who produced the Gospel papyrus manuscripts known as P45, P66, and P75.
bibl.seg: COMFORT Philip Wesley, The Scribe as Interpreter: A New Look at New Testament Textual Criticism According to Reader Reception Theory.

Diss. Univ. of South Africa. Summary in DA 59 (1998-1999) p. 110-A. - The first section deals with the literary theory of reader reception as it pertains to Christian Egyptian scribes living in the second and third centuries A.D.; the second section provides a detailed analysis of the actual receptions and textual variants produced by three Christian Egyptian scribes - i.e., those who produced the Gospel papyrus manuscripts known as P45, P66, and P75.
